title: Top Funds Kick Off 2024 With Huge Bet On MSFT Stock — And 1 Sector
text:
BREAKING: Futures Mixed In the first list of new buys by the best mutual funds to close out 2023 and kick off 2024, leading money managers placed massive bets on MSFT stock, Broadcom (AVGO) and a host of top tech and other companies. But one sector commanded the most demand: building. Microsoft (MSFT) topped this monthly screen, raking in an estimated $17.4 billion. Microsoft holds the distinction of being the only one of the Magnificent Seven stocks to earn a spot on the IBD Long-Term Leaders list. The best mutual funds also scooped up just under $13 billion worth of shares in AVGO stock. Nine more stocks joined the billion-dollar club, including Lululemon Athletica (LULU), Arista Networks (ANET), Netflix (NFLX) and Costco Wholesale (COST). Last month, NFLX stock was featured on the IBD Breakout Stocks Index. Artificial intelligence leaders Adobe (ADBE) and Salesforce.com (CRM) also earned membership. Spearheading huge demand for the building sector, CRH (CRH) cemented its spot on the list as these savvy investors shoveled roughly $1.5 billion into the provider of building materials solutions. The links below highlight a portion of this month's new buys and sells by top funds. Click here to see all the stocks on the list. Magnificent Seven: Why Only MSFT Stock Is A Long-Term Leader Showing clear demand among the best mutual funds, the building sector accounted for 38 of the 200 companies on this month's list. Within the broad building sector, stocks showing institutional demand hailed from seven industry groups. The Construction Products/Miscellaneous group led, featuring 13 firms. Among them were Tecnoglass (TGLS), TopBuild (BLD), Core & Main (CNM) and Owens Corning (OC). Trane Technologies (TT), SmithAO (AOS) and AAON (AAON) joined five others in the A/C & Heating Products industry. On Wednesday, AAON was featured as an IBD 50 stock to watch because of its surging earnings growth in recent quarters. In the homebuilders group, PulteGroup (PHM), Toll Brothers (TOL) and Dream Finders Homes (DFH) were among six companies making the grade. Four industry peers joined CRH in the Cement/Concrete/Aggregates group, including Martin Marietta (MLM) and Summit Materials (SUM). As 2024 gets underway, demand for enterprise software stocks — driven by the AI boom — continues unabated. In addition to CRM stock, Palantir (PLTR), Workday (WDAY), Datadog (DDOG), Dynatrace (DT) and Shopify (SHOP) joined eight more companies in that industry group. A Jefferies analyst just downgraded PLTR stock, calling it "overhyped on AI." In the related but Specialty Enterprise Software group, DoubleVerify (DV), HubSpot (HUBS), Atlassian (TEAM) and AppLovin (APP) made the cut, along with three others.
